text:
THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES
AND SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW.

PRINCE ALBERT, SASK., FRIDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1885.

BANKINGHOUSE
Macarthur & Knowles,
Prince Albert, N.W.T.,
Transact General Banking Business.
Interest allowed on Deposits.
Notes accepted at all points in the District.
Collections undertaken and promptly answered.
BANKERS—Merchant Bank of Canada

WAR DECLARATION
W. C. RAMSAY

There seems now to be no doubt that Red will suffer the extreme penalty of war. The Government has informed the Committee of the Privy Council of England has decided against him. His condemnation is certain, and there is no assurance that no further reprisal could be made.

Excitement over the fate of Red continues to increase. The French government has issued an ultimatum demanding a consultation of statesmen, but Sir John has refused to meet them. The question on the execution taking place on the 11th.

Red's counsel has received information that the French government, as well as additional officials are preparing for a formal commission to pronounce upon the matter.

The Queen has replied to the message of the French government, and the formulation of the death sentence passed by the French government, that Sir John is unable to meet them. The Queen has delegated the pardon to the French government, and Red's counsel is preparing to meet them.

TENDERS
McGuire, Wells Block

Will be received up to
Tuesday, November 10, 1885.
For the immediate occupation and completion of
Instructor's House,
Stables and Storehouse,
On Beaver's Reserve, Duck Lake.

J. M. KAR, Indian Agent.

NOTICE

The partnership heretofore existing, and known under the name of William Knox & Barker, has been dissolved by mutual consent, effective October 26th, 1885.

All debts owing to said partnership, and all claims against said partnership, are hereby discharged.

This notice is given to the former creditors of the firm, and to be paid to settle accounts, William Knox, who will continue the business under his own name.

WILLIAM KNOX,
WILLIAM J. BARKER,
Prince Albert, Sask., N.W.T.
October 23, 1885.

CARD OF THANKS

I feel much pleasure in taking this opportunity to express my thanks to those friends who rendered me able assistance in endeavoring to save my stock during the late fire, as also to express my appreciation of their kind sympathies extended since the occurrence.

I shall be glad to welcome all old customers and as many new ones as possible at the building lately occupied as a post office, next door east of T. J. Agnew's, on my reopening there as soon as the alterations now in progress are completed.

T. E. JACKSON.

NOTICE

On account of my recent loss by fire, I must request all those indebted to me to call and settle their accounts immediately.

I will be found for the present in A. L. Sifton's law offices, next door west of Sturges' store.

T. E. JACKSON.

ROBERT THOMSON,
Sign & Ornamental Painter
Gilding and Powdering
in short orders.
Decorative Painting & Specialty
Commissioning N. W. M. Fisher, Prince Albert.

TENDERS
FOR CHAIRMAN OF Saskatchewan Curling and Skating Rink

Will be received up till
Saturday, November 7, 1885.
Tenders to be handed in to
ANDREW DOGFELLOW,
Chairman of Committee.

CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.

Gathered by our Reporters—

Mr. T. O. Davis returned to town by the last mail.
Mr. R. Armstrong, owner of Riot's opera house, is recovering in hospital from a successful display of Xmas Cards on Cass's location. Call and see them.
Mr. T. Swanton has gone to join the police force in the metropolis of Manitoba for a while in the metropolis of Manitoba.
Sergeant Keenan and party made Indian camp at Sand Branch, and returned on Friday.

A party of twenty men in charge of Sergeant Parker are on the way from Battleford.
Winter, apparently, has again set in. Mr. and Mrs. Smith have left the "Beaver House" for the fall of the "Beaver House."
Mr. and Mrs. J. Courtney have gone to spend the winter in Ireland, and expect to return early next spring.
Sergeant Cathcart has arrived from Regina, and is posted to this Division.
Indian Hostility expected.
Sergeant Douglas and party of twenty men have been with Indian Agent Rae to South Pass and distant an escort on behalf of the Government.
The post office has been removed east of Owen's residence, to a building belonging to Sergt. Keenan, and which has been handsomely fitted up for the purpose.
Chief Factor Belanger was summoned by Mr. Smith, who is recovering, who returned recently and entertained the members of the Band in the most hospitable manner.

The nominations for Mayor and Councilors will take place at Mr. Brewer's office in connection with the election, from 10 o'clock until 12 o'clock. If the weather permits, the election will be held at the same place, from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m., on Monday, Nov. 10th.

The candidates elected will meet at the same place on Monday, Nov. 10th, at 2 o'clock, when they will be sworn in by the returning officer and receive their certificates.

The annual meeting of the Prince Albert Curling Club will be held on Thursday evening, Nov. 1st, at 8 o'clock. There will be a good attendance of members present. The Vice-President, T. N. Campbell, will preside. The Hon. J. F. Brown, President, will make an address on the subject of Management. A Goodfellow Club Spont, R. Grayson, H. F. Montgomery and J. D. Hannafin, will make speeches. Mr. Donaldson, Esq., Hon. L. Clarke, Patrons and Patrons, and Messrs. Smith and Speer. A motion of condolence was passed by the club to Miss Winifred Elliott and the friends of Messrs. Napier and Elliott, who were killed at Duck Lake fight.

LAND GRANTS

To the Editor of the Times:

Sir, Will you kindly inform me why the government has not allowed land grants to the Indians? The Police who are guarding the military during the rebellion, as it has to the militia? You will confer a favor by answering my query as I am much interested in this matter.

INQUIRER.

IN-BACKFUL CONDUITS.

Sir, Would you kindly inform me in your paper a warrant was sent to give to some persons living far from Prince Albert that they must appear and have any complaints they may have against the conduct of the school children, on Sunday, such as bell ringing, beating the Sunday school children, etc. If any person wishes to make complaint again, their names shall be published in the local paper, and in any other way to make examples of us we shall deem necessary.

CHAS ADAMS,
W. H. McLean,
Warren.
THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES

J. D. MAVEETY

PRINCE ALBERT, N.W.T.

FRIDAY, OCT. 30, 1885.

INCORPORATION.

We have at last become a corporate body, under the name of The Town of Prince Albert. The first election for Mayor and Councillors takes place on Thursday, the 12th of November. We believe there are several competent men in the field who will offer themselves for election. The citizens of Prince Albert, in this the first municipal election to be held in this District, should exercise their greatest care in their choice of representatives, electing them in the Council, and only elect those who by a long residence in the District have made themselves thoroughly acquainted with the wants and capabilities of the town. We have been told and greatly felt the want of several improvements that could only be made by united action on the part of the settlement, and it was for this purpose we became incorporated. We believe Prince Albert to be capable of great things, but the time has not yet come when we should embark in any great enterprise or allow any large expenditure of public money. In some future time it may be necessary for us to do in order to keep Prince Albert the leading town in the North West Territories. At present the wardrobes of the Council should be "full," but how much the economy which is afraid to spend a dollar for fear it may be wasted, but the economy of the good business man who looks ahead and spends a little more than what he cannot lose to-day. One of the first things needed is a fire engine. We all felt the want of one last Saturday night when Jackson's drug store was on fire, and no effort could be made to save the building. The fire department now for a fire engine may save us thousands of dollars in the future, and the longer we remain without one the worse it will be for us. Let us hasten forth for the protection of timber were very small, only such men who have large ability for us must perform work to interests at stake in the town and the day when timber will be very scarce interests are the permanent same and we shall be obliged to purchase of Prince Albert, and not fall back on the old expedient of buying land in pioneer sections. It is better in these matters at any rate. Mr. White's talk of guarantee that the railway construction will be carried on in Prince Albert and the rest of the surrounding District. There are one or two points in Mr. White's speech that are well worthy of our attention, and we will briefly enumerate them. In the first place let us procure one or two by saying that the hon. gentleman did not confine himself to the broken track of most public men, who of course at the moment experience the advantages of a position as an outsider, but who delightfully with all his heart has done his best to do them honor, and having made the usual stereotyped reply, at once forget all about it and dismiss the affair from their minds. Mr. White not only expressed to us his satisfaction at the character of the reception accorded to him, but when he left for other parts of the country, referred more than once to what we had done toward the advancement of the town. Mr. White's visit is pleasant one to all of us for us to look back upon. And it is by these little remarks let fall unintentionally that we get all the impressions of the occasion. We finish this subject by saying that whatever was done was meant for the best, and after Mr. White's expressions of gratitude, the trouble expended is now looked upon as a great benefit. The effect of Parliamentary representation is too extensive a one for us to get into at the present time, and the several ideas on it have been already ventilated to such an extent as to make it unnecessary to enter into the fact of the census being taken may be considered as a promise that the matter will not rest here, and we are glad sure that from what we have heard Mr. White will be able to get out of the hands of the bosses. We are glad to see that the hon. gentleman fully recognises the great importance of Railways to this community, for that matter is of vital importance to the North West. In reference to the opening out of the Hudson's Bay route, we must consider it simply a question of time and open communication with shipping points in the Hudson's Bay. We believe that no other country in the world affords such grand facilities for the export of produce, as any railway running in the direction of the Hudson's Bay will be to a great extent assisted and rendered more valuable. There is no doubt that the opening out of the Hudson's Bay route is only a question of time and when this occurs the dependents of the town will be greatly benefited. The unusually heavy growth of land out to the Hudson's Bay Railway Company, and the great endeavours made to ascertain the nature of this mountain outlet, show that the Government is interested at home and fully realize that the railway deeply affects the interests of the country. We must admit that Mr. White's remarks in reference to the

MR. WHITE'S REPLY.

In our last issue we gave at length the Hon. Thos. White's reply to the address presented to him by the citizens of Prince Albert and the people of the surrounding District. There are one or two points in Mr. White's speech that are well worthy of our attention, and we will briefly enumerate them. In the first place let us procure one or two by saying that the hon. gentleman did not confine himself to the broken track of most public men, who of course at the moment experience the advantages of a position as an outsider, but who delightfully with all his heart has done his best to do them honor, and having made the usual stereotyped reply, at once forget all about it and dismiss the affair from their minds. Mr. White not only expressed to us his satisfaction at the character of the reception accorded to him, but when he left for other parts of the country, referred more than once to what we had done toward the advancement of the town. Mr. White's visit is pleasant one to all of us for us to look back upon. And it is by these little remarks let fall unintentionally that we get all the impressions of the occasion. We finish this subject by saying that whatever was done was meant for the best, and after Mr. White's expressions of gratitude, the trouble expended is now looked upon as a great benefit. The effect of Parliamentary representation is too extensive a one for us to get into at the present time, and the several ideas on it have been already ventilated to such an extent as to make it unnecessary to enter into the fact of the census being taken may be considered as a promise that the matter will not rest here, and we are glad sure that from what we have heard Mr. White will be able to get out of the hands of the bosses. We are glad to see that the hon. gentleman fully recognises the great importance of Railways to this community, for that matter is of vital importance to the North West. In reference to the opening out of the Hudson's Bay route, we must consider it simply a question of time and open communication with shipping points in the Hudson's Bay. We believe that no other country in the world affords such grand facilities for the export of produce, as any railway running in the direction of the Hudson's Bay will be to a great extent assisted and rendered more valuable. There is no doubt that the opening out of the Hudson's Bay route is only a question of time and when this occurs the dependents of the town will be greatly benefited. The unusually heavy growth of land out to the Hudson's Bay Railway Company, and the great endeavours made to ascertain the nature of this mountain outlet, show that the Government is interested at home and fully realize that the railway deeply affects the interests of the country. Prince Albert, Sept. 16, 1885.
N.W.M. POLICE
TENDERS FOR BEEF
Tenders will be received by the undersigned up to 12 o'clock noon,
NOVEMBER 1st, 1885.
For supply Beef to Prince Albert, N.W.M.
Prince Albert, July 14th, 1886.

The contract required per day will be about 150 pounds.
Beef to be delivered at the Barracks excepting in exceptional proportions of beef and hind quarters.
The Beef is to be of good quality, and subject to inspection by the officer commanding, who will purchase on the spot at the market price.
Security of the fulfillment of the contract will be required.
Tenderers to state price per pound.
Delivery to commence from the date of the acceptance of the tender.

JAMES SINCLAIR
Merchant Tailor,
No. 31 Main Street

We wish to inform our customer and the public in general, that we have just received our stock of Fall and Winter wear for Gents, Ladies & Children. The largest and most complete assortment to choose from ever brought into Prince Albert.
Shannon & McLeod.

J.D. MAVEETY, PUBLISHER AND PROPRIETOR
3RD ST., PRINCE ALBERT, SASK
BANQUET

To the Hon. Thomas White,
Minister of Interior.

Addressing Addressed by Mr. White,
and the various Representatives
of the Provincial, Municipal, Nat-
uralization, Educational and other
Institutes.

The meeting, in the name of the Hon. T.
White took place Wednesday evening
at the residence of the R. E. Hughes, Esq.,
Mr. White's friend at Athabasca, attended by
representatives. About one hundred sat
down to the table. The chair was oc-
cupied by Mr. Hughes, Esq., who spoke
for the Hon. Mr. White. Then came
the reply by Messrs. J. Macdonald, T.
McKay and Col. Spence. To the right
of the chairman there was seated Mr.
White with Mr. Archibald on McKay's
left. Capt. Perry of the N.W.M.P.
followed by Rev. Mr. McMillan and
Mr. Holmes.

After the inner man had been fully
satisfied and the tables cleared off, the
conversation turned upon the subject
of "Quebec," which was duly honored. The
chairman gave the "Prince of Wales" and the Royalty Family, which was
received with cheer. The next topic
was the "Government General of Canada,"
and carried away the great majority way
for "Particulars of Canada."

The next proposal, coupled with the name
of Mr. John McKeefe, M.P.P., Manitoba,
who spoke for the same, stated that he
had never done more than he had, but
could not do more than he had done. He
believed that the proposal of the Lord
Mayor would be beneficial to both the
government and the people of Prince
Albert. Mr. McKeefe thought that Mr.
White could make a success of the very diffi-
cult position he would now have to fill.

The proposal was too long for a single
column, so the following graphic will be
subject of so much importance as the
"Particulars of Canada."

The chairman gave the well chosen
remarks, then proposed the toast of the
evening, "Our Honor."

Before Mr. White responded, Mr. E.
Hughes introduced the company with a
song, which was rendered in his usual
pleasing style.

Mr. White, on rising, was received
with prolonged cheering. He said he
would be more or less than human if he
did not feel highly honoured; greeted
long and hearty, and expressed upon him a deep sense at the
importance of his proposition. He
had been in the public affairs for about
wars and thirty-five years, and knew how
difficult it was for any person, coming
up, to overcome the prejudices which
much less his opponents. He had re-
ceived kindly greetings from those he
was opposed to, and had the honour of
being friends. He said he was not a milk
and water politician, but was decided in
his opinions, and was backed by his friends
to hit hard when necessary. He believed
in party government, although sometimes there was no party agree-
ment; that there was more than neces-
sary for a whole country. He believed
in the spirit of good government existing
in Canada, that the best, hardworking
government responsive to the people and a
vigilant opposition to watch them at
times, but that they were all working for
the liberation of the people. Since being
sworn into office he had received the
most cordial greetings, and would be
politically successful, and was glad to
see around these tables some who were
not necessarily his party friends. He
knew how difficult it was for any man
to live up to all their expectations, but he hoped by
accurate information, to maintain his
dignity, so as to earn the warmest
accolades. He believed that the
Dominion of Canada had a great future
before it, and that the amalgamation of
the different provinces there would al-
ways be great difficulties for any Cana-
dian Government. He said he would
not forget that the interests of the North
West were the interest of the Dominion,
but he did say that the future prosperity
of Canada depended upon the development
of these regions. He then pro-
posed a hearty toast for the
North West, characterising them as an
energetic, ambitious and progressive
people who did not have to wait for
us to do with the building up of this great
country, but had laid in his day of
its soil, and was ready to help build
upon these promises. He again
thanked them for the kindness of their
greeting, and received his most aman-
uently applauding.

When questions had again been re-
ceived, Mr. Adam Maclean, for the
chairman, rose and proposed the toast,
"The land we live in," coupled with the
name of Mr. Thomas McKay, Esq., Mr.
Kay. It was found that he had left to
make preparations for his dinner in the
city of Ottawa, but Mr. McKay, who
hadly called for, responded in his usual
masterly style. On rising, he paid a
tribute to the kindliness and hospitality
allotted to the great country in which
we lived, and said that it only needed to
be known what was done to get it.
He then referred at length to the great
advantages that Canada offered, partic-
ularly the new and exciting way of
wayfaring. He also suggested the
advantages of the railway for the
traffic between the South Saskatchewan
and used jointly by all the railways
that connected to Prince Albert. He
then complimented the representatives
from the different parts of Canada who had so
pleasantly joined hands to help suppress
their enemies, particularly the French,
while giving high tribute to the Hon. Minister of the
Interior upon his carryout to carry out
how important his future prosperity was
intended to be with the medical profession.

Mr. Miller said he had lived in the
country for a number of years, and could
speak from experience. He thought
that he had ten good crops out of eleven.
He believed that we had as good a climate
as there was anywhere in the world, and
was confident that this country would not
only be a great stock raising country, but
also a great producer of grain in the
country. He briefly referred to the bet-
ting on contracts, and believed in the
great benefits that would come from
and get the benefits, which under the
large contract system they did not get.

He referred to the advantages of the
Hudson Bay railway, and made a few
remarks on the timber dues, from which
he said he had one month's salary. He
also referred to the present government, as
he thought it was highly pleasant with the way
the matters were being handled.

Capt. Howze said he believed agri-
culture would prosper in this district, and
thought that the climate was very fit
right to the bitter end. He also referred
to every confidence in the country.

Capt. Craig made a neat and interest-
ing speech, referring to the advantages
of the country, and had every
confidence in its great future. He
believed the cost of producing grain
would prove a profit to everyone.

The next toast proposed was: "The
Army, Navy and Volunteers of Canada,"
coupled with the names of Capt. Perry,
Young and Hoey.

Each of these gentlemen replied in a
neat and appropriate speech.

Capt. Perry then rose and made a
few remarks thanking the chairman and
the people of Prince Albert for always
standing by the fellow citizen.

The next proposal was: "The
Province of Ontario and Canada" was then
proposed and responded to by R. E.
Hughes, Esq., the member elected by
the day. He addressed a short and polite
speech.

Mr. W. J. Barker then sang "The
Union Jack of Old England," which was
followed by a hearty applause.

Mr. John Stewart, in a few very ap-
propriate remarks, then proposed
"Bachelors and Spinsters," coupled
with the names of Messrs. Maclean,
Belanger and Betts. Each of these
gentlemen replied with a speech to reply.

Mr. McCrory, who has recently moved
town, having considerable business
with the farmers and the business men
of the town, complimented them upon
their good financial standing and the
prominence with which they had always
met their obligations.

Mr. Edward Johnson then sang a song,
which was given in excellent style and
was loudly applauded.

Mr. Stewart then proposed the
"Clergy," coupled with the names of
the Rev. Mr. McMillan and Archdeacon
McKay.

Archdeacon McKay also replied in
a very neat and appropriate speech.

The Legal Profession, was next
proposed, coupled with the names
of Messrs. Maclean, Gam, Newlands and
Sifton. These gentlemen each very ably
responded, each doing credit to his calling,
which was reflected upon the ability of two representa-
tives of Blackstone.

The next toast proposed was the
"Medical Profession," coupled with the
name of Dr. Porter.

Dr. Porter, in his reply, made a very
neat speech dwelling on the benefits
which the country would certainly show
itself in its future prosperity was
intended to be with the medical profession.

Col. Spence then proposed "The
National Intercourse," coupled with the
names of Capt. Flett, Messrs. Stewart and
Messrs. Maclean.

Mr. Stewart, in reply, referred to cir-
culars that had been received by secreta-
ries of some of the school districts
in the province. He stated that
there was nothing to fear, that owing to their not being well
enough educated, half of the country, if not
more, would be without the means of
bettering themselves. He thought that
it was a great injustice, and hoped that
it might be rectified by such
measures as were mentioned. He referred
to the opening of the old school, and
showed the great benefits that would be derived
therefrom.

Mr. Stewart referred to the phantom
gift box to be presented on such an im-
portant occasion, and said he was glad
to see the members of the committee
who were one of the representatives of
the Dominion of Canada. He believed
this country from its great natural re-
sources will ever be considered the
dominant power of Canada. It was
glad as a representative of the entire
province, interested in identity interes-
ting them in the advancement of the
nation and the advancement of our
country, so as to make homes for ourselves.
He thought that the representatives
of this country could or should be per-
suaded to give their attention to such
an energetic and substantial as those who
were interested in the advancement of
this country from its greatest natural
resources, and that the members of the
province should be given the support
of the teachers to fail by the payment
of the fees and taxes of the

The next toast proposed was: "The
Lawyers," coupled with the name of F. N.
Baker. Mr. Baker replied in his usual
pleasing style.

The Mechanical Industry, was next
proposed, coupled with the names
of W. A. Carter and W. J. Barker.

Mr. Carter replied in a few very neat
words, and Mr. Baker sang "Let me
have a glass of wine."

Col. Spence then proposed the "Press
of Canada," to which Mr. J. D. Mavety
of the P.A. Times replied.

The next toast proposed was: "The
Dry Goods, Hats, Ready Made Clothing,
Boots and Shoes, etc.

Morton's Celebrated Jams, Jellies, Pickles, Confectionery Teas and Sugar,

Ogilvie's Flour,
Which we will sell cheap for cash.

O. E. HUGHES & CO.

T. N. CAMPBELL,
Bookseller and Stationer

A LARGE ASSORTMENT OF
ROOM AND PICTURE MOULDINGS.
PICTURES
Mounted and Framed.

Orders for Books from Great Britain, Toronto, Montreal, United States promptly attended.
